template.name: Cisco Catalyst 3750V2-24PS SNMP
template.description:
Template Cisco Catalyst 3750V2-24PS
MIBs used: CISCO-MEMORY-POOL-MIB IF-MIB EtherLike-MIB SNMPv2-MIB CISCO-PROCESS-MIB CISCO-ENVMON-MIB ENTITY-MIB
Template tooling version used: 0.38

trigger.name: Unavailable by ICMP ping
trigger.description: Last three attempts returned timeout. Please check device connectivity.

item.name: SNMP traps (fallback)
item.description: Item is used to collect all SNMP traps unmatched by other snmptrap items

item.name: System contact details
item.description: MIB: SNMPv2-MIB The textual identification of the contact person for this managed node, together with information on how to contact this person. If no contact information is known, the value is the zero-length string.

item.name: System description
item.description: MIB: SNMPv2-MIB A textual description of the entity. This value should include the full name and version identification of the system's hardware type, software operating-system, and networking software.

trigger.name: Device has been replaced (new serial number received)
trigger.description: Device serial number has changed. Ack to close

item.name: System location
item.description: MIB: SNMPv2-MIB The physical location of this node (e.g., `telephone closet, 3rd floor'). If the location is unknown, the value is the zero-length string.

item.name: System name
item.description: MIB: SNMPv2-MIB An administratively-assigned name for this managed node.By convention, this is the node's fully-qualified domain name. If the name is unknown, the value is the zero-length string.

trigger.name: System name has changed (new name: {ITEM.VALUE})
trigger.description: System name has changed. Ack to close.

item.name: System object ID
item.description: MIB: SNMPv2-MIB The vendor's authoritative identification of the network management subsystem contained in the entity. This value is allocated within the SMI enterprises subtree (1.3.6.1.4.1) and provides an easy and unambiguous means for determining`what kind of box' is being managed. For example, if vendor`Flintstones, Inc.' was assigned the subtree1.3.6.1.4.1.4242, it could assign the identifier 1.3.6.1.4.1.4242.1.1 to its `Fred Router'.

trigger.name: Operating system description has changed
trigger.description: Operating system description has changed. Possible reasons that system has been updated or replaced. Ack to close.

item.name: Uptime
item.description: MIB: SNMPv2-MIB The time (in hundredths of a second) since the network management portion of the system was last re-initialized.

trigger.name: No SNMP data collection
trigger.description: SNMP is not available for polling. Please check device connectivity and SNMP settings.

discovery_rule.name: CPU discovery
discovery_rule.description: If your IOS device has several CPUs, you must use CISCO-PROCESS-MIB and its object cpmCPUTotal5minRev from the table called cpmCPUTotalTable , indexed with cpmCPUTotalIndex . This table allows CISCO-PROCESS-MIB to keep CPU statistics for different physical entities in the router, like different CPU chips, group of CPUs, or CPUs in different modules/cards. In case of a single CPU, cpmCPUTotalTable has only one entry.

item_prototype.name: #{#SNMPINDEX}: CPU utilization
item_prototype.description: MIB: CISCO-PROCESS-MIB Object name: cpmCPUTotal5minRev The cpmCPUTotal5minRev MIB object provides a more accurate view of the performance of the router over time than the MIB objects cpmCPUTotal1minRev and cpmCPUTotal5secRev . These MIB objects are not accurate because they look at CPU at one minute and five second intervals, respectively. These MIBs enable you to monitor the trends and plan the capacity of your network. The recommended baseline rising threshold for cpmCPUTotal5minRev is 90 percent. Depending on the platform, some routers that run at 90 percent, for example, 2500s, can exhibit performance degradation versus a high-end router, for example, the 7500 series, which can operate fine. Reference: http://www.cisco.com/c/en/us/support/docs/ip/simple-network-management-protocol-snmp/15215-collect-cpu-util-snmp.html

trigger_prototype.name: #{#SNMPINDEX}: High CPU utilization (over {$CPU.UTIL.CRIT}% for 5m)
trigger_prototype.description: CPU utilization is too high. The system might be slow to respond.

trigger_prototype.name: {#ENT_NAME}: Device has been replaced (new serial number received)
trigger_prototype.description: Device serial number has changed. Ack to close

discovery_rule.name: FAN discovery
discovery_rule.description: The table of fan status maintained by the environmental monitor.

discovery_rule.name: Memory discovery
discovery_rule.description: Discovery of ciscoMemoryPoolTable, a table of memory pool monitoring entries. http://www.cisco.com/c/en/us/support/docs/ip/simple-network-management-protocol-snmp/15216-contiguous-memory.html

item_prototype.name: {#SNMPVALUE}: Free memory
item_prototype.description: MIB: CISCO-MEMORY-POOL-MIB Object name: ciscoMemoryPoolFree Indicates the number of bytes from the memory pool that are currently unused on the managed device. Note that the sum of ciscoMemoryPoolUsed and ciscoMemoryPoolFree is the total amount of memory in the pool Reference: http://www.cisco.com/c/en/us/support/docs/ip/simple-network-management-protocol-snmp/15216-contiguous-memory.html

item_prototype.name: {#SNMPVALUE}: Used memory
item_prototype.description: MIB: CISCO-MEMORY-POOL-MIB Object name: ciscoMemoryPoolUsed Indicates the number of bytes from the memory pool that are currently in use by applications on the managed device. Reference: http://www.cisco.com/c/en/us/support/docs/ip/simple-network-management-protocol-snmp/15216-contiguous-memory.html

trigger_prototype.name: {#SNMPVALUE}: High memory utilization ( >{$MEMORY.UTIL.MAX}% for 5m)
trigger_prototype.description: The system is running out of free memory.

item_prototype.name: Interface {#IFNAME}({#IFALIAS}): Inbound packets discarded
item_prototype.description: MIB: IF-MIB The number of inbound packets which were chosen to be discarded even though no errors had been detected to prevent their being deliverable to a higher-layer protocol. One possible reason for discarding such a packet could be to free up buffer space. Discontinuities in the value of this counter can occur at re-initialization of the management system, and at other times as indicated by the value of ifCounterDiscontinuityTime.

item_prototype.name: Interface {#IFNAME}({#IFALIAS}): Inbound packets with errors
item_prototype.description: MIB: IF-MIB For packet-oriented interfaces, the number of inbound packets that contained errors preventing them from being deliverable to a higher-layer protocol. For character-oriented or fixed-length interfaces, the number of inbound transmission units that contained errors preventing them from being deliverable to a higher-layer protocol. Discontinuities in the value of this counter can occur at re-initialization of the management system, and at other times as indicated by the value of ifCounterDiscontinuityTime.

trigger_prototype.name: Interface {#IFNAME}({#IFALIAS}): High input error rate ( > {$IF.ERRORS.WARN:"{#IFNAME}"} for 5m)

item_prototype.name: Interface {#IFNAME}({#IFALIAS}): Bits received
item_prototype.description: MIB: IF-MIB The total number of octets received on the interface, including framing characters. This object is a 64-bit version of ifInOctets. Discontinuities in the value of this counter can occur at re-initialization of the management system, and at other times as indicated by the value of ifCounterDiscontinuityTime.

item_prototype.name: Interface {#IFNAME}({#IFALIAS}): Outbound packets discarded
item_prototype.description: MIB: IF-MIB The number of outbound packets which were chosen to be discarded even though no errors had been detected to prevent their being deliverable to a higher-layer protocol. One possible reason for discarding such a packet could be to free up buffer space. Discontinuities in the value of this counter can occur at re-initialization of the management system, and at other times as indicated by the value of ifCounterDiscontinuityTime.

item_prototype.name: Interface {#IFNAME}({#IFALIAS}): Outbound packets with errors
item_prototype.description: MIB: IF-MIB For packet-oriented interfaces, the number of outbound packets that contained errors preventing them from being deliverable to a higher-layer protocol. For character-oriented or fixed-length interfaces, the number of outbound transmission units that contained errors preventing them from being deliverable to a higher-layer protocol. Discontinuities in the value of this counter can occur at re-initialization of the management system, and at other times as indicated by the value of ifCounterDiscontinuityTime.

trigger_prototype.name: Interface {#IFNAME}({#IFALIAS}): High output error rate ( > {$IF.ERRORS.WARN:"{#IFNAME}"} for 5m)

item_prototype.name: Interface {#IFNAME}({#IFALIAS}): Bits sent
item_prototype.description: MIB: IF-MIB The total number of octets transmitted out of the interface, including framing characters. This object is a 64-bit version of ifOutOctets.Discontinuities in the value of this counter can occur at re-initialization of the management system, and at other times as indicated by the value of ifCounterDiscontinuityTime.

item_prototype.name: Interface {#IFNAME}({#IFALIAS}): Speed
item_prototype.description: MIB: IF-MIB An estimate of the interface's current bandwidth in units of 1,000,000 bits per second. If this object reports a value of `n' then the speed of the interface is somewhere in the range of `n-500,000' to`n+499,999'. For interfaces which do not vary in bandwidth or for those where no accurate estimation can be made, this object should contain the nominal bandwidth. For a sub-layer which has no concept of bandwidth, this object should be zero.

item_prototype.name: Interface {#IFNAME}({#IFALIAS}): Operational status
item_prototype.description: MIB: IF-MIB The current operational state of the interface. - The testing(3) state indicates that no operational packet scan be passed - If ifAdminStatus is down(2) then ifOperStatus should be down(2) - If ifAdminStatus is changed to up(1) then ifOperStatus should change to up(1) if the interface is ready to transmit and receive network traffic - It should change todormant(5) if the interface is waiting for external actions (such as a serial line waiting for an incoming connection) - It should remain in the down(2) state if and only if there is a fault that prevents it from going to the up(1) state - It should remain in the notPresent(6) state if the interface has missing(typically, hardware) components.

trigger_prototype.name: Interface {#IFNAME}({#IFALIAS}): Link down
trigger_prototype.description: This trigger expression works as follows: 1. Can be triggered if operations status is down. 2. {$IFCONTROL:"{#IFNAME}"}=1 - user can redefine Context macro to value - 0. That marks this interface as not important. No new trigger will be fired if this interface is down.

item_prototype.name: Interface {#IFNAME}({#IFALIAS}): Interface type
item_prototype.description: MIB: IF-MIB The type of interface. Additional values for ifType are assigned by the Internet Assigned NumbersAuthority (IANA), through updating the syntax of the IANAifType textual convention.

trigger_prototype.expression: {Cisco Catalyst 3750V2-24PS SNMP:net.if.speed[{#SNMPINDEX}].change()}<0 and {Cisco Catalyst 3750V2-24PS SNMP:net.if.speed[{#SNMPINDEX}].last()}>0 and ( {Cisco Catalyst 3750V2-24PS SNMP:net.if.type[{#SNMPINDEX}].last()}=6 or {Cisco Catalyst 3750V2-24PS SNMP:net.if.type[{#SNMPINDEX}].last()}=7 or {Cisco Catalyst 3750V2-24PS SNMP:net.if.type[{#SNMPINDEX}].last()}=11 or {Cisco Catalyst 3750V2-24PS SNMP:net.if.type[{#SNMPINDEX}].last()}=62 or {Cisco Catalyst 3750V2-24PS SNMP:net.if.type[{#SNMPINDEX}].last()}=69 or {Cisco Catalyst 3750V2-24PS SNMP:net.if.type[{#SNMPINDEX}].last()}=117 ) and ({Cisco Catalyst 3750V2-24PS SNMP:net.if.status[{#SNMPINDEX}].last()}<>2)
trigger_prototype.name: Interface {#IFNAME}({#IFALIAS}): Ethernet has changed to lower speed than it was before
trigger_prototype.description: This Ethernet connection has transitioned down from its known maximum speed. This might be a sign of autonegotiation issues. Ack to close.

trigger_prototype.expression: ({Cisco Catalyst 3750V2-24PS SNMP:net.if.in[{#SNMPINDEX}].avg(15m)}>({$IF.UTIL.MAX:"{#IFNAME}"}/100)*{Cisco Catalyst 3750V2-24PS SNMP:net.if.speed[{#SNMPINDEX}].last()}) and {Cisco Catalyst 3750V2-24PS SNMP:net.if.speed[{#SNMPINDEX}].last()}>0
trigger_prototype.name: Interface {#IFNAME}({#IFALIAS}): High inbound bandwidth usage ( > {$IF.UTIL.MAX:"{#IFNAME}"}% )
trigger_prototype.description: The network interface utilization is close to its estimated maximum bandwidth.

trigger_prototype.expression: ({Cisco Catalyst 3750V2-24PS SNMP:net.if.out[{#SNMPINDEX}].avg(15m)}>({$IF.UTIL.MAX:"{#IFNAME}"}/100)*{Cisco Catalyst 3750V2-24PS SNMP:net.if.speed[{#SNMPINDEX}].last()}) and {Cisco Catalyst 3750V2-24PS SNMP:net.if.speed[{#SNMPINDEX}].last()}>0
trigger_prototype.name: Interface {#IFNAME}({#IFALIAS}): High outbound bandwidth usage ( > {$IF.UTIL.MAX:"{#IFNAME}"}% )
trigger_prototype.description: The network interface utilization is close to its estimated maximum bandwidth.

discovery_rule.name: EtherLike discovery
discovery_rule.description: Discovering interfaces from IF-MIB and EtherLike-MIB. Interfaces with up(1) Operational Status are discovered.

item_prototype.name: Interface {#IFNAME}({#IFALIAS}): Duplex status
item_prototype.description:
MIB: EtherLike-MIB Object name: dot3StatsDuplexStatus The current mode of operation of the MAC entity. 'unknown' indicates that the current duplex mode could not be determined.
Management control of the duplex mode is accomplished through the MAU MIB. When an interface does not support autonegotiation, or when autonegotiation is not enabled, the duplex mode is controlled using ifMauDefaultType. When autonegotiation is supported and enabled, duplex mode is controlled using ifMauAutoNegAdvertisedBits. In either case, the currently operating duplex mode is reflected both in this object and in ifMauType.
Note that this object provides redundant information with ifMauType. Normally, redundant objects are discouraged. However, in this instance, it allows a management application to determine the duplex status of an interface without having to know every possible value of ifMauType. This was felt to be sufficiently valuable to justify the redundancy. Reference: [IEEE 802.3 Std.], 30.3.1.1.32,aDuplexStatus.

trigger_prototype.name: Interface {#IFNAME}({#IFALIAS}): In half-duplex mode
trigger_prototype.description: Please check autonegotiation settings and cabling

discovery_rule.name: PSU discovery
discovery_rule.description: The table of power supply status maintained by the environmental monitor card.

trigger_prototype.name: {#SNMPVALUE}: Power supply is in critical state
trigger_prototype.description: Please check the power supply unit for errors

trigger_prototype.name: {#SNMPVALUE}: Power supply is in warning state
trigger_prototype.description: Please check the power supply unit for errors

dependency.name: {#SNMPVALUE}: Power supply is in critical state

discovery_rule.name: Temperature discovery
discovery_rule.description: Discovery of ciscoEnvMonTemperatureTable (ciscoEnvMonTemperatureDescr), a table of ambient temperature status maintained by the environmental monitor.

item_prototype.name: {#SNMPVALUE}: Temperature status
item_prototype.description: MIB: CISCO-ENVMON-MIB Object name: ciscoEnvMonTemperatureState The current state of the test point being instrumented.

trigger_prototype.name: {#SNMPVALUE}: Temperature is in critical state
trigger_prototype.description: This trigger uses temperature sensor state

trigger_prototype.name: {#SNMPVALUE}: Temperature is in warning state
trigger_prototype.description: This trigger uses temperature sensor state

item_prototype.name: {#SNMPVALUE}: Temperature
item_prototype.description: MIB: CISCO-ENVMON-MIB Object name: ciscoEnvMonTemperatureValue The current measurement of the test point being instrumented.

trigger_prototype.name: {#SNMPVALUE}: Temperature is above critical threshold: >{$TEMP_CRIT:"{#SNMPVALUE}"}
trigger_prototype.description: This trigger uses temperature sensor values as well as temperature sensor status if available

trigger_prototype.name: {#SNMPVALUE}: Temperature is above warning threshold: >{$TEMP_WARN:"{#SNMPVALUE}"}
trigger_prototype.description: This trigger uses temperature sensor values as well as temperature sensor status if available

macro.description: Filter out loopbacks, nulls, docker veth links and docker0 bridge by default
